title: CNN's Anderson Cooper slammed for using final question to ask about Ellen DeGeneres and George Bush
text:
CNN's Anderson Cooper was slammed last night for using his final question during the Democratic debate to ask about Ellen DeGeneres cozying up to George Bush, when there had been no questions about climate change or China.

Cooper invited candidates to name an unlikely friend and used DeGeneres and Bush as an example after they were pictured laughing with each other at a Dallas Cowboys game earlier this month.

DeGeneres was criticized by members of the LGBTQ community who pointed to Bush's views on gay marriage, as well as by others who invoked the memory of the Iraq War.

But Cooper was accused of trivializing the debate and squandering three hours of air time by not questioning candidates on more pressing matters, such as climate change or relations with China.

Moderator and CNN anchor Anderson Cooper speaks on stage ahead of the fourth Democratic primary debate in Ohio last night

George Bush and Ellen DeGeneres sit together at the Dallas Cowboys game on October 6

The Mayor of San Antonio, Julian Castro, tweeted: 'Three hours and no questions tonight about climate, housing, or immigration. Climate change is an existential threat. America has a housing crisis. Children are still in cages at our border.

'But you know, Ellen.'

In response to Cooper's question many named former and current colleagues from across the aisle, Bernie Sanders mentioned Utah Senator Mike Lee; Kamala Harris said Senator Rand Paul; and Tulsi Gabbard said former Representative Trey Gowdy.

Two of the candidates named Senator John McCain, Amy Klobuchar and Joe Biden, who delivered a eulogy at McCain's funeral.

Klobuchar, in a moving description, recounted how the late Senator, too ill to speak to her when she visited him before he died, pointed to a line in his book.

'There is nothing more liberating in life than fighting for a cause larger than yourself,' Klobuchar quoted.

Meghan McCain later tweeted that Klobuchar's answer was 'beautiful' but many others tweeted their anger at what they perceive were wasted minutes which could have been spent scrutinizing the candidates.

Two of the candidates named Senator John McCain, Amy Klobuchar and Joe Biden, who delivered a eulogy at McCain's funeral

A former spokesperson for President Barack Obama, Tommy Vietor, simply wrote: 'NO. NO YOU ARE NOT CLOSING WITH AN ELLEN QUESTION.'

And Washington Governor Jay Inslee, who had campaigned for the presidency with a focus on climate change, before dropping out, tweeted: 'Not one single question about the climate crisis.

'This is the existential crisis of our time. Not one single question, and that's completely inexcusable.'
description: Cooper invited candidates to name a unlikely friend and used DeGeneres and Bush as an example after they were pictured laughing with each other at a Dallas Cowboys match earlier this month.
